meanings.def: money that you pay to use a particular road or bridge
examples: motorway tolls
a toll bridge
the possibility of imposing tolls on some motorways
a low hourly rate of pay
interest rates
an admission charge
legal fees
an annual membership fee
a parking fine

meanings.def: the amount of damage or the number of deaths and injuries that are caused in a particular war, disaster, etc.
examples: the war’s growing casualty toll
Every hour, the news bulletin reported the mounting toll of casualties.

meanings.def: the sound of a bell ringing with slow, regular sounds
a charge for a phone call that is calculated at a higher rate than a local call
to have a bad effect on somebody/something; to cause a lot of damage, deaths, pain, etc.
examples: Illness had taken a heavy toll on her.
The recession is taking its toll on the housing markets.
The pressure of fame can take a terrible toll.

idioms.idiom: take a heavy toll (on somebody/something) | take its toll (on somebody/something)
idioms.def: to have a bad effect on somebody/something; to cause a lot of damage, deaths, pain, etc.
examples: Illness had taken a heavy toll on her.
The recession is taking its toll on the housing markets.
The pressure of fame can take a terrible toll.

meanings.def: when a bell tolls or somebody tolls it, it is rung slowly many times, especially as a sign that somebody has died
examples: toll (for somebody) The Abbey bell tolled for those killed in the war.
Ask not for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.
toll something The bell tolled the hour.
(figurative) The revolution tolled the death knell (= signalled the end) for the Russian monarchy.
